A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: Everyone is dealing with heroes and legends\, and how they fail... as people it shows how we want the legend so badly… it’s even the theme with the audience... we want the legend\, not the man. Rey was troubled that her hero\, Luke\, was this disheveled hermit who didn’t want anything to do with the Jedi. Rose was heartbroken that “The Finn” was a deserter (even though he was just being a homie to Rey)\, Poe had to deal with Admiral Holdo of rebellion legend history\, who wasn’t what he wanted her to be\, Kylo struggled with Snoke\, even Luke had to deal with Yoda. But at the end of the day\, in the eyes of a child\, heroes are heroes. And there’s hope in that. More hope than in most of the film\, bc in that you have rebirth. It’s very elegantly told\, bro. It’s a mad powerful story. The most complex of any star wars\, and the truest in terms of its side quest storytelling.... that’s very OT era--but even that isn’t a waste bc we learn that there is always purpose\, even in those moments that seem like error\, or that result in failure where coincidence breeds light. It’ll be debated a long while\, and it’s because it’s divisive. This isn’t Abrams. And I love Force Awakens\, but it’s just fanfare. You know? It gave people what they wanted out of the characters there\, and introduced some fun new stuff. Very Abrams. He’s like Spielberg fused with Michael Bay. He gives you some heart\, but he’s also gonna give you exactly what you’re asking for cause he’s such a fan pleaser. Johnson gives you things that are hard to deal with. It’s a much harder story to tell. People keep going on about Luke almost killing Kylo and how it’s not Luke.... Like 1. we don’t know what dude has gone through in the 30 plus years since the OT\, and let’s pray that he’s not the same guy\, and 2. Did we not all watch ROTJ where he almost kills Vader and then decides to stop? [Lets talk about Rey for a second] Rey is already hella force sensitive. We know this from the first film. She’s already trained in hand to hand combat. We see that in TFA too. Yoda confirms that she already has what it takes\, she just needs guidance. Luke gives her that with his resolve to drain all of his force energy in that fire force projection. As for Luke\, what he does feels like an Obi Wan move... or a Yoda move... just all philosophy... and that line\, “see you around\, kid”? Tell me that’s not one of the best lines of any movie. What a put down. [As for Finn and Rose] I know that the scenes were meant to establish that relationship\, and also to bring in that kid for the pay off at the end\, and also to say that things don’t go the way you think they’re meant to\, with them almost getting to the actual codebreaker and then getting in jail and meeting Del Toro’s character. Overall I liked the movie but there were some major holes. Who is Snoke and how did he get into power? Where are the Knights of Ren? Why didn’t Luke teach Rey anything?
